hypotheses.title: Lazarus Group Medusa Ransomware Deployment via Compromised Supply Chain or Credential Theft
hypotheses.description: Lazarus Group has recently adopted Medusa ransomware in attacks targeting healthcare, financial services, and government sectors across the Middle East and U.S. The group leverages supply chain compromise and credential-based access. We should hunt for Medusa-related artifacts, lateral movement via RDP/PSExec, and indicators of Medusaâ€™s execution chain.

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution logs (especially PowerShell, cmd.exe), file creation/modification timestamps for .exe, .dll, .ps1 files, memory dumps for Medusa strings
Outbound connections to known C2 domains/IPs, DNS queries for Medusa-related subdomains, unusual SMB/RDP traffic volumes
Failed login attempts followed by successful logins, unusual geographic logins, MFA bypass events
tools: Microsoft Sentinel, Okta, CrowdStrike Falcon Identity

hunting_tactics.description: Search for Medusa-specific file artifacts and execution patterns
sample_queries: index=endpoint sourcetype=win* (Image="*\medusa.exe" OR Image="*\Medusa*.exe" OR Image="*\medusa*.dll")
index=endpoint sourcetype=sysmon EventID=1 (CommandLine="*medusa*" OR CommandLine="*Medusa*" OR CommandLine="*Ransomware*")
index=network dest_port=445 OR dest_port=139 (dns_query="*medusa*" OR dns_query="*lazarus*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Medusa.exe, Medusa.dll, Medusa ransom note files (e.g., _DECRYPT_FILES_*.txt), PowerShell scripts with Medusa-related strings

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Credential Theft Followed by Lateral Movement
hunting_tactics.description: Detect credential harvesting followed by RDP/PSExec lateral movement, typical of Lazarus campaigns
sample_queries: index=security sourcetype=win* EventID=4624 Logon_Type=10 AND (Logon_Process="seclogo" OR Authentication_Package="Negotiate") | stats count by user, src_ip, dest_host | where count > 3
index=endpoint sourcetype=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\psexec.exe" OR Image="*\PsExec64.exe" OR Image="*\wmiprvse.exe") AND (CommandLine="*cmd.exe*" OR CommandLine="*powershell*")
index=network dest_port=3389 AND (src_ip IN ("192.168.*", "10.*", "172.16.*")) AND dest_host IN ("*dc*", "*file*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Multiple RDP logins to domain controllers or file servers within 5 minutes, PsExec usage with cmd/powershell, credential dumping tools (mimikatz, lsass.exe access)

network_patterns: RDP (3389) from internal to internal hosts
SMB (445) to multiple hosts in quick succession
DNS queries with Medusa or Lazarus-related subdomains
other_indicators: Use of PowerShell with -enc or -encodedcommand flags
Execution of cmd.exe via WMI or WScript
Creation of scheduled tasks with Medusa payloads

recommended_actions: Isolate hosts showing Medusa-related artifacts immediately
Revoke and reset credentials for all users on affected hosts
Block outbound connections to suspicious domains/IPs identified in network logs
Review and harden RDP access policies, enforce MFA and network segmentation

hypotheses.title: ShinyHunters Data Exfiltration via Credential Compromise or Third-Party Vendor Breach
hypotheses.description: ShinyHunters has breached multiple high-profile organizations including CarGurus, Wynn Resorts, Figure, and Canada Goose. Their typical TTPs include credential stuffing, phishing, and third-party vendor compromise. We should hunt for indicators of credential theft (e.g., password spray, MFA fatigue), unusual data movement, and access to SaaS platforms like Salesforce or Zendesk.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1048.003 - Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Failed login attempts (EventID 4625), MFA failures, logins from new IPs/countries, anomalous session durations
tools: Microsoft Sentinel, Okta, Azure AD Audit Logs, CrowdStrike Identity

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Salesforce login events, API calls to Zendesk/Salesforce, data export events, privilege escalations
tools: Salesforce Shield, Microsoft Cloud App Security, Palo Alto Prisma Cloud

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Browser extension installs, Chrome profile exports, clipboard monitoring, file access to sensitive directories

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Credential Theft and Password Spray Detection
hunting_tactics.description: Detect credential stuffing and password spray attacks preceding ShinyHunters-style breaches
sample_queries: index=security sourcetype=win* EventID=4625 (Account_Name!="*$" AND Account_Name!="ANONYMOUS LOGON") | stats count by Account_Name, src_ip | where count > 10
index=security sourcetype=azuread EventID=50001 OR EventID=50053 OR EventID=50126 | stats count by user, ipaddr | where count > 5
index=endpoint sourcetype=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\mimikatz*" OR Image="*\mimilib.dll" OR CommandLine="*sekurlsa*" OR CommandLine="*lsadump*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Multiple failed logins for common usernames (e.g., admin, support), logins from Tor exit nodes or known proxy IPs, credential dumping tools

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: SaaS Platform Compromise and Data Exfiltration
hunting_tactics.description: Detect unauthorized access to SaaS platforms (e.g., Salesforce, Zendesk) and large data exports
sample_queries: index=salesforce (action="login" OR action="api_call") (status="failure" OR status="success") | stats count by user, src_ip | where count > 100
index=cloud sourcetype=msgraph Data_Access_Event="export" AND (File_Type="csv" OR File_Type="xlsx" OR File_Type="json") AND Size > 100MB

index=endpoint sourcetype=sysmon EventID=1 (CommandLine="*curl*" OR CommandLine="*wget*" OR CommandLine="*powershell*" OR CommandLine="*net use*") AND (CommandLine="*s3://*" OR CommandLine="*dropbox*" OR CommandLine="*google drive*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Bulk exports of user data, access to Salesforce/Zendesk from new IPs, use of cloud storage APIs for exfiltration

network_patterns: Large outbound HTTPS traffic to cloud storage providers (Dropbox, Google Drive, S3)
DNS queries to known phishing domains
Unusual outbound traffic to SaaS platforms
user_agent_strings: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/120.0.0.0 Safari/537.36 (ShinyHunters bot)
other_indicators: Use of stolen credentials from past breaches (e.g., LinkedIn, Adobe)
MFA fatigue attacks (multiple MFA prompts in short time)

recommended_actions: Enforce MFA across all SaaS platforms and block legacy authentication
Review and restrict Salesforce/Zendesk API access policies
Implement data loss prevention (DLP) for large exports and cloud storage uploads
Scan for compromised credentials using HaveIBeenPwned and breach databases

hypotheses.title: SmartLoader Campaigns Using AI-Themed Supply Chain Compromise (e.g., Oura MCP Clone)
hypotheses.description: SmartLoader has been observed cloning legitimate AI projects (e.g., Oura MCP server) to distribute StealC infostealer. This supply chain compromise leverages trust in AI tooling and GitHub forks. We should hunt for fake GitHub repositories, malicious npm/PyPI packages, and StealC execution artifacts.

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution logs, PowerShell command lines, file creation in %TEMP%, registry run keys
DNS queries for GitHub/GitLab subdomains, HTTP/HTTPS requests to GitHub, npm/PyPI endpoints
tools: Zeek, Palo Alto Networks, Cisco Umbrella

data_sources_needed.specific_data: npm/PyPI package downloads, GitHub repository clones, CI/CD pipeline logs
tools: GitHub Advanced Security, GitGuardian, Snyk, Jfrog Xray

hunting_tactics.description: Search for GitHub repositories mimicking legitimate AI projects (e.g., Oura MCP) with suspicious activity
sample_queries: index=github sourcetype=git_clone (repo_url="*ouramcp*" OR repo_url="*oura*" OR repo_url="*mcp*") AND (fork_count=0 OR stars<5) AND (commit_count<10 OR created_at>"2025-12-01")

index=endpoint sourcetype=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\node.exe" OR Image="*\python.exe") AND (CommandLine="*npm install*" OR CommandLine="*pip install*") AND (CommandLine="*ouramcp*" OR CommandLine="*stealc*")
index=network dest_domain="github.com" (dns_query="*stealc*" OR dns_query="*ouramcp*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Repositories with low stars/forks but high download counts, fake contributor profiles, recent creation dates, use of StealC or Oura MCP names

hunting_tactics.description: Detect StealC infostealer execution and persistence mechanisms
sample_queries: index=endpoint sourcetype=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\rundll32.exe" OR Image="*\regsvr32.exe" OR Image="*\mshta.exe") AND (CommandLine="*stealc*" OR CommandLine="*StealC*")
index=endpoint sourcetype=win* EventID=4688 (NewProcessName="*\cmd.exe" OR NewProcessName="*\powershell.exe") AND (CommandLine="*stealc*" OR CommandLine="*StealC*")
index=endpoint sourcetype=sysmon EventID=1 (CommandLine="*reg add HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run /v StealC*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: StealC.exe, StealC.dll, rundll32 regsvr32 mshta with StealC arguments, registry run keys for persistence

network_patterns: DNS queries to GitHub with StealC/Ouramcp subdomains
HTTP/HTTPS to GitHub with unusual file extensions (.bin, .dat)
Outbound connections to known C2 IPs (e.g., 185.220.101.x)
other_indicators: Fake GitHub forks with no commits
npm packages with malicious scripts in package.json
PyPI packages with setup.py executing remote code

recommended_actions: Block npm/PyPI packages with known malicious hashes
Audit GitHub repositories for fake forks and suspicious activity
Implement strict code signing policies for internal AI tools
Monitor for StealC execution artifacts and C2 communication

hypotheses.title: ClickFix Campaigns Using DNS Tunneling and AI-Assisted Social Engineering
hypotheses.description: ClickFix has evolved to use DNS tunneling via nslookup to deliver malware (e.g., ModeloRAT, MacSync) and is increasingly using AI-generated guides and hijacked Google Ads. We should hunt for DNS exfiltration patterns, fake AI guides, and malicious nslookup commands in PowerShell/cmd.

data_sources_needed.specific_data: DNS queries with encoded payloads in subdomains, nslookup commands, unusual DNS TXT/NULL record queries
tools: Zeek, Cisco Umbrella, Palo Alto Networks

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Command-line logs for nslookup, PowerShell with encoded commands, suspicious process chains
Google Ads with fake AI guides, phishing emails with CAPTCHA lures, malicious PDFs
tools: Microsoft Defender for Office 365, Google Ads Transparency Center

hunting_tactics.description: Detect DNS-based ClickFix variants using nslookup for payload delivery
sample_queries: index=network dest_port=53 (dns_query="*cmd.exe*" OR dns_query="*powershell*" OR dns_query="*mshta*" OR dns_query="*rundll32*")
index=endpoint sourcetype=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\nslookup.exe" OR Image="*\cmd.exe") AND (CommandLine="*nslookup*" AND (CommandLine="*txt*" OR CommandLine="*null*" OR CommandLine="*base64*"))
index=network dest_domain="*.com" (dns_query="*clickfix*" OR dns_query="*nslookup*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup queries with base64-encoded payloads in subdomains, DNS TXT queries returning PowerShell commands, suspicious nslookup usage in command chains

hunting_tactics.description: Detect fake AI guides and hijacked Google Ads used in ClickFix campaigns
sample_queries: index=web sourcetype=proxy (url="*claude*" OR url="*gemini*" OR url="*chatgpt*") AND (url="*guide*" OR url="*tutorial*" OR url="*fix*") AND (url="*macsync*" OR url="*modelorat*")
index=google_ads (ad_destination_url="*clickfix*" OR ad_destination_url="*nslookup*") AND (ad_status="active" OR ad_status="approved")
index=endpoint sourcetype=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\chrome.exe" OR Image="*\msedge.exe") AND (CommandLine="*google.com/search*" AND CommandLine="*clickfix*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Google Ads linking to fake AI guides, searches for ClickFix or nslookup guides, execution of PowerShell from browser downloads

network_patterns: HTTP/HTTPS to GitHub/GitLab with malicious scripts
Outbound connections to known C2 IPs (e.g., 185.220.101.x)
other_indicators: Fake CAPTCHA lures with instructions to run nslookup/powershell
Google Ads with AI-themed copy but malicious destinations

recommended_actions: Block DNS queries with base64-encoded subdomains
Monitor for nslookup usage in command chains
Audit Google Ads for fake AI guides and malicious destinations
Implement strict browser security policies to prevent drive-by downloads

hypotheses.title: AI Agent Compromise via OpenClaw Stealer and Open Source Registry Abuse
hypotheses.description: OpenClaw, an autonomous AI agent, has been targeted by infostealers stealing its configuration files, API keys, and tokens. Attackers are also compromising open-source registries (e.g., npm, PyPI) to distribute malicious OpenClaw packages. We should hunt for OpenClaw configuration exfiltration, compromised npm packages, and AI agent abuse in CI/CD pipelines.

data_sources_needed.specific_data: File access to OpenClaw config files, process execution of OpenClaw, API key usage
npm/PyPI package downloads, CI/CD pipeline logs, OpenClaw usage in scripts
tools: GitHub Advanced Security, GitGuardian, Snyk, Jfrog Xray

data_sources_needed.specific_data: API key usage, token generation, agent privilege escalations

hunting_tactics.description: Detect infostealers targeting OpenClaw configuration files and tokens
sample_queries: index=endpoint sourcetype=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\infostealer*" OR Image="*\stealc*" OR Image="*\lumma*") AND (CommandLine="*openclaw*" OR CommandLine="*clawdbot*" OR CommandLine="*clawdbot*")
index=endpoint sourcetype=win* EventID=4656 (Object_Name="*\openclaw*" OR Object_Name="*\clawdbot*" OR Object_Name="*\clawdbot*") AND (Access_List="*ReadData*" OR Access_List="*ReadAttributes*")
index=network dest_domain="*.com" (dns_query="*openclaw*" OR dns_query="*clawdbot*" OR dns_query="*clawdbot*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: OpenClaw config files (e.g., config.json, settings.yaml), API keys in OpenClaw directories, exfiltration of OpenClaw tokens

hunting_tactics.description: Detect compromised npm/PyPI packages distributing OpenClaw or infostealers
sample_queries: index=github sourcetype=git_clone (repo_url="*openclaw*" OR repo_url="*clawdbot*") AND (fork_count>0 OR stars>10) AND (commit_count>50 OR created_at<"2025-12-01")

index=endpoint sourcetype=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\node.exe" OR Image="*\python.exe") AND (CommandLine="*npm install*" OR CommandLine="*pip install*") AND (CommandLine="*openclaw*" OR CommandLine="*clawdbot*")
index=network dest_domain="npmjs.com" (dns_query="*openclaw*" OR dns_query="*clawdbot*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Fake OpenClaw repositories with high stars/forks, malicious npm/PyPI packages with OpenClaw names, CI/CD pipelines installing OpenClaw packages

network_patterns: DNS queries to npmjs.com with OpenClaw/Clawdbot subdomains
HTTP/HTTPS to GitHub with malicious scripts
Outbound connections to known C2 IPs (e.g., 185.220.101.x)
other_indicators: Fake OpenClaw repositories with high stars/forks
npm packages with malicious scripts in package.json

recommended_actions: Audit OpenClaw configurations and revoke compromised tokens
Block npm/PyPI packages with known malicious hashes
Implement strict code signing policies for internal AI tools
Monitor for OpenClaw execution artifacts and C2 communication

unique_mitre_techniques: T1048.003 - Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
